title: How to Make Rose Butter

steps.headline: Choose the rose petals.
steps.description: The best rose petals for this recipe are those that are highly scented. The old-fashioned rose types such as rugosa, musk, damask or Eglantine roses are good choices. Be sure to choose rose petals that have not been sprayed with chemicals. They must be organic petals. Wash and allow to dry thoroughly before using in this recipe.

steps.headline: Remove the petals from the flower head.
Place the butter in the mixing bowl.
Whisk the butter and petals together.
Form balls using two wooden spoons.
steps.description: Roll back and forth on the spoon head until a ball shape forms.

steps.headline: Place on a small dish covered in wax or baking (parchment) paper.
steps.description: Place the dish inside the airtight container and seal.

steps.headline: Place the rose butter balls into the refrigerator to set.
steps.description: They're ready to serve once they've firmed up.

text: Choose the rose petals. The best rose petals for this recipe are those that are highly scented. The old-fashioned rose types such as rugosa, musk, damask or Eglantine roses are good choices. Be sure to choose rose petals that have not been sprayed with chemicals. They must be organic petals. Wash and allow to dry thoroughly before using in this recipe. Remove the petals from the flower head.  Place the butter in the mixing bowl. Add the petals. Whisk the butter and petals together. Mix until combined. Form balls using two wooden spoons. Roll back and forth on the spoon head until a ball shape forms. Place on a small dish covered in wax or baking (parchment) paper. Place the dish inside the airtight container and seal. Place the rose butter balls into the refrigerator to set. They're ready to serve once they've firmed up.
